definition: lit. catch fish then forget the trap (idiom, from Zhuangzi 莊子|庄子); fig. to take help for granted
to obtain/to get/to gain/to catch (a disease)/proper/suitable/proud/contented/to allow/to permit/ready/finished
structural particle: used after a verb (or adjective as main verb), linking it to following phrase indicating effect, degree, possibility etc
to have to/must/ought to/to need to
surname Yu
fish/CL:條|条[tiao2],尾[wei3]
to forget/to overlook/to neglect
bamboo fish trap
lit. a notch on the side of a boat to locate a sword dropped overboard (idiom); fig. an action made pointless by changed circumstances
lit. climb a tree to catch a fish (idiom); fig. to attempt the impossible
to see the ox already cut up into joints (idiom); extremely skilled/able to see through the problem at one glance
happen unexpectedly/turn out contrary to one's expectations
to pluck a pearl from the black dragon (idiom, from Zhuangzi); fig. to pick out the salient points (from a tangled situation)/to see through to the nub
to buy a wooden box and return the pearls inside/to show poor judgment (idiom)

lit. Ying writes a letter and Yan reads it/fig. to misinterpret the original meaning/to pile up errors/refers to the letter from capital 郢[Ying3] of 楚[Chu3] in which the inadvertent words "hold up the candle" are mistaken by the minister of 燕[Yan1] as "promote the wise"
(literary) how is one to know?
to neglect the root and pursue the tip (idiom)/to neglect fundamentals and concentrate on details
not to be taken as an example/not an example to be followed/not to be taken as authoritative
Jiang Ziya is fishing, if you want take the hook (idiom, refers to early sage 姜子牙 fishing with no bait and the hook above the water); to put one's head in the noose
pinyin: tai4 gong1 diao4 yu2 , yuan4 zhe3 shang4 gou1

definition: to aim to carve a swan and get a semblance of a duck (idiom)/to fail utterly in trying to copy something/to get a reasonably good, if not perfect, result
so dedicated as to forget one's meals (idiom)
whatever you like/to do as one pleases
one's words reflect one's thinking (idiom)
to understand/to comprehend the ultimate essence of things (Buddhism)
